modules.title: Scene Size-up
modules.description: The critical first steps before approaching a patient.

content.content: Ensure your own safety first. If you get hurt, you can't help anyone else.
Do not enter an unsafe scene. Wait for professionals or resources if necessary.
Determine the Mechanism of Injury (MOI) for trauma patients or Nature of Illness (NOI) for medical patients.
Look for clues: fallen rocks, bike crash, pill bottles, medical alert tags.
Body Substance Isolation (BSI). Put on gloves and other PPE as appropriate.
Determine the number of patients. This changes your triage and resource management.
Form a general impression. Is this a critical life threat or a minor issue?

modules.title: Primary Assessment
modules.description: Identify and treat immediate life threats (ABCDE).

content.content:
1. Open the airway (Head-Tilt/Chin-Lift or Jaw Thrust).
2. Look, Listen, and Feel for obstruction.
3. Clear obstructions if visible.
Check for breathing quality and rate.
If not breathing, start CPR immediately.
Check for a pulse (carotid or radial). Check for severe bleeding.

1. Control severe bleeding with direct pressure.
2. Check skin color, temperature, and moisture (CSM).
Assess Level of Responsiveness (LOR) using the AVPU scale.

A: Alert
V: Verbal
P: Pain
U: Unresponsive
Protect the spine if MOI suggests spinal injury.
Expose injuries if necessary, but keep the patient warm. Protect from the elements.

modules.title: Secondary Assessment
modules.description: Complete physical exam, vitals, and history.

content.content: Perform a full Head-to-Toe exam looking for injuries.
Look, Listen, Feel. Compare sides for symmetry.

- Pulse (Rate, Rhythm, Quality)
- Respiration (Rate, Rhythm, Quality)
- Blood Pressure (if available)
- Skin (Color, Temp, Moisture)
- Pupils (PERRL)
- LOR (A+Ox4)

S: Symptoms
A: Allergies
M: Medications
P: Past Medical History
L: Last Ins/Outs
E: Events leading up
